wikipedia_page.main:
Charles Lewis (died 1863) was an English rower who was twice winner of the Wingfield Sculls, the amateur sculling championship of the River Thames.
Lewis was an early member of Leander Club and competed unsuccessfully for the Wingfield sculls in the first race in 1830. He beat the champion James Bayford in the 1831 race. He was defeated by A. A. Julius in 1832, but won the championship back from him in 1833.

response: *Charles Lewis (sculler) (died 1863), winner of the Wingfield Sculls in 1831 and 1833
*Charles Lewis (New Zealand politician) (1857–1927), New Zealand politician
*Sir Charles Lewis, 1st Baronet (1825–1893), Member of Parliament for Londonderry City, 1872–1886, and North Antrim, 1887–1892
*Charles Lewis (soldier) (1733–1774), Virginian colonel killed in the Battle of Point Pleasant, namesake of Lewis County, West Virginia
*Charles Lewis Jr. (1963–2009), co-founder of Tapout clothing
*Charles Lewis African American Veteran who was lynched on December 16, 1918
*Charles Lewis (journalist) (born 1953), founder of the Center for Public Integrity

Bayford was the son of John Bayford, a London magistrate, and his wife Frances who lived in the region of St Pancras London. He was educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge where he became a proficient rower. Bayford won the Wingfield Sculls in 1830 against seven challengersThe Sporting Magazine 1831 but lost in the following year to Charles Lewis.

Julius challenged the Wingfield Sculls champion Charles Lewis in 1832 and won the race. Lewis won the championship back in 1833. But Julius was then so preeminent that he put off challengers in 1834 and 1835 and won with row-overs.Wingfield Sculls Record of Races
